    Standardise GWAS

    standardise_gwas.Rmd

    Here is a simple example of using the genepi.utils::GWAS() object to standardise your GWAS input ready for use with other features in this package. First some unprocessed example data:

    library(genepi.utils)

filepath <- system.file("extdata", "example2_gwas_sumstats.tsv", package="genepi.utils")

gwas <- data.table::fread(filepath)

gwas
#>           MARKER   CHR       POS   BETA    SE     P      EAF     A1     A2
#>           <char> <int>     <int>  <num> <num> <num>    <num> <char> <char>
#>  1: 10:100000625    10 100000625 -0.037 0.137 0.781 7.10e-05      G      A
#>  2: 10:100000645    10 100000645  0.045 0.173 0.961 1.21e-01      C      A
#>  3: 10:100003242    10 100003242 -0.037 0.134 0.480 5.04e-07      G      T
#>  4: 10:100003785    10 100003785 -0.008 0.137 0.743 1.55e-01      C      T
#>  5: 10:100004360    10 100004360  0.045 0.134 0.961 8.38e-01      A      G
#>  6: 10:100004906    10 100004906 -0.037 0.173 0.781 7.40e-01      A      C
#>  7: 10:100004996    10 100004996 -0.008 0.137 0.743 3.23e-10      A      G
#>  8: 10:100005282    10 100005282 -0.147 0.134 0.781 9.30e-04      T      C
#>  9: 10:100007362    10 100007362  0.045 0.173 0.961 8.16e-05      C      G
#> 10: 10:100008436    10 100008436 -0.008 0.208 0.743 9.46e-04      A      G

    Column mapping

    A number of column mapping options for standard GWAS formats are provided through the ColumnMap() class.

    • a string - valid id for a pre-defined map (e.g. ‘giant’ or ‘gwama’)
    • an unnamed character vector or list - the constructor will create a ColumnMap object as long as the provided column names are found within the list of known aliases
    • a named character vector or list - the names must be the standard column names to map to, and the values the current column names
    • a list of Column class objects 
    # possible inputs to mapping object
colmap_input1 <-    c('MARKER', 'CHR', 'POS', 'BETA', 'SE', 'P', 'EAF', 'A1', 'A2') # will try to guess standard name mapping
colmap_input2 <- list(rsid='MARKER', chr='CHR', bp='POS', beta='BETA', se='SE', p='P', eaf='EAF', ea='A1', oa='A2') # standard naming
colmap_input3 <- list(Column(name='rsid', alias=c('MARKER'), type='character'),
                      Column(name='chr',  alias=c('CHR'),    type='character'),
                      Column(name='bp',   alias=c('POS'),    type='integer'),
                      Column(name='beta', alias=c('BETA'),   type='numeric'),
                      Column(name='se',   alias=c('SE'),     type='numeric'),
                      Column(name='p',    alias=c('P'),      type='numeric'),
                      Column(name='eaf',  alias=c('EAF'),    type='numeric'),
                      Column(name='ea',   alias=c('A1'),     type='character'),
                      Column(name='oa',   alias=c('A2'),     type='character'))

# column mapping object
map <- ColumnMap("ns_map")
map <- ColumnMap(colmap_input1)
map <- ColumnMap(colmap_input2)
map <- ColumnMap(colmap_input3)

map
#> <genepi.utils::ColumnMap>
#>  @ map:List of 9
#>  .. $ rsid: <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  ..  ..@ name : chr "rsid"
#>  ..  ..@ alias: chr "MARKER"
#>  ..  ..@ type : chr "character"
#>  .. $ chr : <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  ..  ..@ name : chr "chr"
#>  ..  ..@ alias: chr "CHR"
#>  ..  ..@ type : chr "character"
#>  .. $ bp  : <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  ..  ..@ name : chr "bp"
#>  ..  ..@ alias: chr "POS"
#>  ..  ..@ type : chr "integer"
#>  .. $ beta: <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  ..  ..@ name : chr "beta"
#>  ..  ..@ alias: chr "BETA"
#>  ..  ..@ type : chr "numeric"
#>  .. $ se  : <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  ..  ..@ name : chr "se"
#>  ..  ..@ alias: chr "SE"
#>  ..  ..@ type : chr "numeric"
#>  .. $ p   : <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  ..  ..@ name : chr "p"
#>  ..  ..@ alias: chr "P"
#>  ..  ..@ type : chr "numeric"
#>  .. $ eaf : <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  ..  ..@ name : chr "eaf"
#>  ..  ..@ alias: chr "EAF"
#>  ..  ..@ type : chr "numeric"
#>  .. $ ea  : <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  ..  ..@ name : chr "ea"
#>  ..  ..@ alias: chr "A1"
#>  ..  ..@ type : chr "character"
#>  .. $ oa  : <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  ..  ..@ name : chr "oa"
#>  ..  ..@ alias: chr "A2"
#>  ..  ..@ type : chr "character"

    Standardise GWAS

    A GWAS can then be standardised like so:

    filepath <- system.file("extdata", "example2_gwas_sumstats.tsv", package="genepi.utils")

gwas <- GWAS(dat=filepath, map=map)
#> Loading GWAS ...
#> [i] loading data from: example2_gwas_sumstats.tsv
#> [i] applying column mapping
#> [i] enforcing column types
#> [i] standardising columns
#> [i] standardising allele coding
#> [i] applying filters
#> [i] checking rsid coding
#>  [?] 10 rsids could not be parsed, setting to chr:bp

gwas
#> <genepi.utils::GWAS>
#>  @ map        : <genepi.utils::ColumnMap>
#>  .. @ map:List of 9
#>  .. .. $ rsid: <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  .. ..  ..@ name : chr "rsid"
#>  .. ..  ..@ alias: chr "MARKER"
#>  .. ..  ..@ type : chr "character"
#>  .. .. $ chr : <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  .. ..  ..@ name : chr "chr"
#>  .. ..  ..@ alias: chr "CHR"
#>  .. ..  ..@ type : chr "character"
#>  .. .. $ bp  : <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  .. ..  ..@ name : chr "bp"
#>  .. ..  ..@ alias: chr "POS"
#>  .. ..  ..@ type : chr "integer"
#>  .. .. $ beta: <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  .. ..  ..@ name : chr "beta"
#>  .. ..  ..@ alias: chr "BETA"
#>  .. ..  ..@ type : chr "numeric"
#>  .. .. $ se  : <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  .. ..  ..@ name : chr "se"
#>  .. ..  ..@ alias: chr "SE"
#>  .. ..  ..@ type : chr "numeric"
#>  .. .. $ p   : <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  .. ..  ..@ name : chr "p"
#>  .. ..  ..@ alias: chr "P"
#>  .. ..  ..@ type : chr "numeric"

#>  .. ..  ..@ name : chr "eaf"
#>  .. ..  ..@ alias: chr "EAF"

#>  .. .. $ ea  : <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  .. ..  ..@ name : chr "ea"
#>  .. ..  ..@ alias: chr "A1"
#>  .. ..  ..@ type : chr "character"
#>  .. .. $ oa  : <genepi.utils::Column>
#>  .. ..  ..@ name : chr "oa"
#>  .. ..  ..@ alias: chr "A2"

#>  .. $ !is.na(p)                          : int(0)

#>  @ beta       : num [1:10] -0.037 0.045 -0.037 -0.008 0.045 -0.037 -0.008 -0.147 0.045 -0.008
#>  @ se         : num [1:10] 0.137 0.173 0.134 0.137 0.134 0.173 0.137 0.134 0.173 0.208

    As data.table

    A GWAS object can be easily converted to data.table.

    g <- as.data.table(gwas)

g
#>             rsid    chr        bp     ea     oa      eaf   beta    se     p
#>           <char> <char>     <int> <char> <char>    <num>  <num> <num> <num>
#>  1: 10:100000625     10 100000625      G      A 7.10e-05 -0.037 0.137 0.781
#>  2: 10:100000645     10 100000645      C      A 1.21e-01  0.045 0.173 0.961
#>  3: 10:100003242     10 100003242      G      T 5.04e-07 -0.037 0.134 0.480
#>  4: 10:100003785     10 100003785      C      T 1.55e-01 -0.008 0.137 0.743
#>  5: 10:100004360     10 100004360      A      G 8.38e-01  0.045 0.134 0.961
#>  6: 10:100004906     10 100004906      A      C 7.40e-01 -0.037 0.173 0.781
#>  7: 10:100004996     10 100004996      A      G 3.23e-10 -0.008 0.137 0.743
#>  8: 10:100005282     10 100005282      T      C 9.30e-04 -0.147 0.134 0.781
#>  9: 10:100007362     10 100007362      C      G 8.16e-05  0.045 0.173 0.961
#> 10: 10:100008436     10 100008436      A      G 9.46e-04 -0.008 0.208 0.743
#>         n ncase  trait     id
#>     <int> <int> <char> <char>
#>  1:    NA    NA  trait     id
#>  2:    NA    NA  trait     id
#>  3:    NA    NA  trait     id
#>  4:    NA    NA  trait     id
#>  5:    NA    NA  trait     id
#>  6:    NA    NA  trait     id
#>  7:    NA    NA  trait     id
#>  8:    NA    NA  trait     id
#>  9:    NA    NA  trait     id
#> 10:    NA    NA  trait     id

    Custom quality control

    A GWAS object is created after a number of data checks and filters. The default filters can be altered via the filters argument, which takes a named list of strings that can be evaluated as expressions to filter a data.table. The results of the filtering can be found in the @qc property of the GWAS object which is a named list of integer vectors identifying rows that fail that particular filter.

    gwas <- data.table::fread(filepath)

gwas <- GWAS(dat     = gwas, 
             map     = map, 
             filters = list(beta_invalid = "!is.infinite(beta) & abs(beta) < 10",
                            eaf_invalid  = "eaf >= 0.01 & eaf <= 0.99",
                            p_invalid    = "!is.infinite(p) & sign(p) != -1 & p < 1",
                            se_invalid   = "!is.infinite(se) & abs(se) < 10",
                            chr_missing  = "!is.na(chr)",
                            bp_missing   = "!is.na(bp)",
                            beta_missing = "!is.na(beta)",
                            se_missing   = "!is.na(se)",
                            p_missing    = "!is.na(p)",
                            eaf_missing  = "!is.na(eaf)"))
#> Loading GWAS ...
#> [i] applying column mapping
#> [i] enforcing column types
#> [i] standardising columns
#> [i] standardising allele coding
#> [i] applying filters
#>  [-] 6 row warning(s) with filter 'eaf_invalid' [eaf >= 0.01 & eaf <= 0.99]
#> [i] checking rsid coding
#>  [?] 10 rsids could not be parsed, setting to chr:bp

gwas@qc
#> $`!is.infinite(beta) & abs(beta) < 10`
#> integer(0)
#> 
#> $`eaf >= 0.01 & eaf <= 0.99`
#> [1]  1  3  7  8  9 10
#> 
#> $`!is.infinite(p) & sign(p) != -1 & p < 1`
#> integer(0)
#> 
#> $`!is.infinite(se) & abs(se) < 10`
#> integer(0)
#> 
#> $`!is.na(chr)`
#> integer(0)
#> 
#> $`!is.na(bp)`
#> integer(0)
#> 
#> $`!is.na(beta)`
#> integer(0)
#> 
#> $`!is.na(se)`
#> integer(0)
#> 
#> $`!is.na(p)`
#> integer(0)
#> 
#> $`!is.na(eaf)`
#> integer(0)
#> 
#> $fail
#> [1]  1  3  7  8  9 10
